{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3393887,"name":"Tomer Danielli","username":"Tomerul","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e9bcb4/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T14:34:34.488Z","cooked":"

What computers is your team using to run solidworks? our team currently has computers with i7 9700kf, quadro p600, and 16gb of ram and we are really struggling to run our main robot assembly on them. We have only noticed them being ridiculously slow in the past year, so we are wondering if there is a specific cause for them being slow and not just ‚Äúthey‚Äôre old and slow‚Äù (especially because they‚Äôre not that old), maybe solidworks PDM which we have only started using the past year. We are also probably going to format all of them because we have found a virus on one of them which slowed it down.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T14:34:34.488Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":34,"reads":323,"readers_count":322,"score":234.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467070,"topic_slug":"solidworks-pc-specs","display_username":"Tomer Danielli","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53080,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-pc-specs/467070/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3393892,"name":"Evan McDonald","username":"Yatsuda","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yatsuda/{size}/219223_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T14:43:35.936Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm not too familiar with the p-series GPUS but I imagine you‚Äôre gonna wanna upgrade it if it‚Äôs a rendering issue. The p600 is a decade old at this point, but I imagine the rest of your hardware is fine. If you can, I‚Äôd swap the GPU for something more modern.

Edit: didn‚Äôt notice you said quadro, whoops. Quadro came out in 2017

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T14:50:11.672Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":321,"readers_count":320,"score":64.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467070,"topic_slug":"solidworks-pc-specs","display_username":"Evan McDonald","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57803,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Finally a senior üò≠"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-pc-specs/467070/2","custom_user_title":"Finally a senior üò≠","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393895,"name":"Clayton Ramsey","username":"ClayTownR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T14:50:30.885Z","cooked":"

There are also a few tricks you can do to improve SW performance.

  • First, do a performance evaluation to get a sense for the number of triangles in the scene. You can also do assembly visualization to highlight the objects and subassemblies with the most triangles. Typically imported STEPs, especially motors, are the biggest offenders - I recommend remodeling them natively or at least cranking down the resolution and suppressing invisible parts in them.
  • Disable RealView graphics. If you can tolerate it, using a shaded-only view (instead of shaded with edges) is usually much more performant but also a pain.
  • Make liberal use of the Freeze Bar to prevent rebuilds wherever possible. I usually freeze every single part as soon as I‚Äôm done working with it.
  • SW has a few memory leaks inside that causes massive slowdowns after about half an hour to an hour of work. There‚Äôs no fix for this other than just periodically restarting it.

In my experience, the bottleneck for SW is rarely the GPU, since SW is mostly a single-threaded program. If your slowdowns occur when panning around the scene, that‚Äôs a GPU or RAM issue, but if it‚Äôs when mating parts or moving things, then it‚Äôs a CPU or RAM issue. If both of those are fast and file opening is slow, that‚Äôs probably an SSD issue.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T14:50:30.885Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":295,"readers_count":294,"score":104.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467070,"topic_slug":"solidworks-pc-specs","display_username":"Clayton Ramsey","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28741,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"100 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-pc-specs/467070/3","custom_user_title":"100 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393897,"name":"Adam Fleming","username":"AdamF","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/adamf/{size}/234717_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T14:56:49.913Z","cooked":"
ClayTownR:

Typically imported STEPs, especially motors, are the biggest offenders

Another big offender is nuts and bolts that have the threads modeled in. It adds up when you have a large amount. Try to use the built in tool for hardware if it is available, or create your own library with just cosmetic threads applied.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T14:56:49.913Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":257,"readers_count":256,"score":106.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":467070,"topic_slug":"solidworks-pc-specs","display_username":"Adam Fleming","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41952,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-pc-specs/467070/4","custom_user_title":"FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393940,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T17:09:40.177Z","cooked":"

SOLIDWORKS is still single-threaded. Your CPU still has a decent single thread rating. It‚Äôll do fine with some tweaks.

  • Make sure you‚Äôre getting to the 4.9GHz turbo speed (clean your heatsinks, reapply thermal paste)
  • Disable HT if applicable
  • Disable all fancy rendering/graphics
  • Update drivers
  • No modeled threads
  • No working from network drives/folders
  • Use geometry patterns when possible
  • NO IN-CONTEXT RELATIONS

My work desktop uses a 9700K and does fine with absurd SW models (tens of thousands of patterned holes). It is also water-cooled and I‚Äôve applied the above tricks.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-31T17:10:31.918Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":95.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":467070,"topic_slug":"solidworks-pc-specs","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/solidworks-pc-specs/467070/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3393952,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-31T17:40:09.649Z","cooked":"

Every standard (SHCS, BHCS, FHCS) McMaster fastener solidworks model has thread features which are easily suppressible with no ill effects, so no need to make your own library unless you want to.

If you find yourself using ‚Äúcopy with mates‚Äù a ton, consider patterns instead. Patterned components are much lighter computationally than calculating additional mates.

Solidworks has a performance visualization tool, which was mentioned above by claytown. The triangles is a good first place to start inside that tool, then I like to look at the load times and rebuild times for the entire assembly. If you have anything taking more than 1-3 seconds to load/rebuild, you usually have a problem and want to try to identify it. Sometimes you‚Äôll see a single assembly needs to rebuild multiple times upon each overall rebuild. This usually indicates you have some circular reference that you‚Äôll want to resolve.

any OTs items with a ton of surfaces/bodies/faces is going to kill you. Motors, PCA‚Äôs, chain, gears, tread, etc are classic killers here.

Motors and PCA‚Äôs you can delete or suppress as many bodies/surfaces as you can which aren‚Äôt actually helping you figure out clearance to surrounding components or whatever is important to you. Unfortunately sometimes these get exported as single solid bodies which is the absolute worst.

Gears you could consider remodeling as toothless cylinders at the pitch diameter of the gear.

Don‚Äôt use chain in your models - model the profile of the chain as a single solid body instead.

Don‚Äôt use modeled tread in your assemblies.

Parts with tons of appearances applied to them (ex: PDH) are slower too. Consider removing appearances where you can.

If you want any of the above for making nice renders, you can make a configuration for renders where everything has correct visual properties, but is very slow to manipulate, and your working configuration is as minimalistic as possible
